author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Gasoline prices hiked sharply in Turkmenistan
summary: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan — Turkmenistan, which once provided drivers a quota of free gasoline every month, has raised its pump prices by 50 percent as the country struggles with low prices for its mainstay export of natural gas. On Thursday, a liter of gasoline rose to 1.5 manat, the equivalent of 42 U.S. cents ($1.60 per gallon). Although the price is still low by world standards, the increase is substantial in a country where the average monthly wage is estimated to be about $350. Turkmenistan is heavily reliant on its vast natural gas reserves for export income. As gas prices fell on the world market, Turkmenistan's GDP declined about 15 percent since 2014. author: captainunderoos
title: Nintendo announces ‘Mario Kart Tour’ for smartphones, Nintendo Switch Online release date
summary: Nintendo on Wednesday night announced on Twitter that Mario Kart Tour will be its next mobile game. Nintendo says that the app is in development now and will launch by March 2019, which marks the end of the company's next fiscal year. Unfortunately, that's all that the company was willing to share about the game. Providing that it launches before the Legend of Zelda game that is presumably still in the works, Mario Kart Tour will be the fifth first-party mobile game from Nintendo since it invested in mobile, following Miitomo and Super Mario Run in 2016 as well as Fire Emblem Heroes and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp last year. In addition to the Mario Kart announcement, Nintendo also confirmed that the Nintendo Switch Online service will launch in September 2018. Similar to Xbox Live or PlayStation Network, the service was initially set to launch last fall, but was then pushed back to 2018. Nintendo refrained from sharing any specifics in terms of a launch date (or even a window), but now we know that it won't be ready for prime time until the fall. Nintendo Switch Online will cost $19.99 for a year-long membership, $7.99 for three months or $3.99 for one month. Beyond online play, the online service will also include a Classic Game Selection feature which will allow subscribers to download a classic Nintendo title for free, such as Super Mario Bros. 3 for the NES. Further details regarding Mario Kart Tour and the long-awaited Nintendo Switch Online subscription service are likely incoming, but for now, all we have is the information that Nintendo shared in tweets on Wednesday.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Logan Paul: 'I'm a good guy who made a bad decision,' in first interview after controversy
summary: Logan Paul sat down with ABC's Good Morning America on Thursday for his first television interview since facing severe backlash over a controversial video that appeared to show the body of an alleged suicide victim in Japan. The 22-year-old social media star — who deleted the video, apologized, shut down his page, and then created a suicide prevention video in the wake of the controversy – said posting the clip was “a horrible lapse in judgment” and he “can, will and [is] going to learn from it and be a better person.” “It's not like I'm a bad guy,” he said. “I'm a good guy who made a bad decision.” “This has been the hardest time in my life,” he added. “I've never been hated by the whole world.

author: DeltaBravo
title: People Have Figured Out A Way To Totally Avoid The Miramar Map In 'PUBG'
summary: Last month, PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds unveiled the new "Miramar" map to much fanfare, promising players a new desert-themed murder playground to contrast with the vaguely Eastern European Erangel. A few months later and the thing just doesn't seem all that popular: there's a lack of item balance that can cause you real trouble if you drop in the wrong parts of the map, it has long stretches of desert with no cover and all in all the gameplay felt different enough that players would quit and reload in order to go back to the original Erangel. It's not a great scene. Developer PUBG Corp. addressed the problems in a recent patch, hoping to placate a fanbase that prefers to stick with what's

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Forget the SNES Classic, this $34 box plays every NES and SNES game ever
summary: We do our best to give you a heads up anytime the Super NES Classic Edition is in stock at any online stores, since so many people out there have been trying to find them. If you ask us, however, skip it. It’s a nifty retro console but the Hyperkin RetroN 2 Gaming Console is so much better. It only costs $34 and change, and it plays every single SNES game cartridge ever released. Oh, and it also plays every NES game cartridge, so it’s basically two retro consoles in one. Here are the highlights from Amazon’s product page: Play all your classic Nintendo favorites in the Retron 2 two-in-one system! Compatible with all NES and SNES games, the Retron 2 delivers hours of old-school fun. Comes with two wired controllers and supports classic NES and SNES controllers. Plays NES and SNES games Comes with one wired NES and SNES Controller Compatible with NES and SNES controllers

author: DeltaBravo
title: 'Dragon Ball FighterZ' Review: Goku Said To Knock You Out
summary: There are two types of gamers who play fighting games and these two types of gamers look for two very different things when reading reviews of fighting games. First, there's the casual crowd. These gamers may play all sorts of video games—they may, indeed, be “hardcore” gamers in a broad sense of the word—but when it comes to fighting games they're just here for the story mode and some local brawls. They've played fighting games before—some Street Fighter, some Mortal Kombat, maybe some Injustice or Tekken—but they aren't competitive players and they don't get into the nitty gritty of each game's mechanics. Then there's the competitive crowd. These players are part of the Fighting Game Community

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: I was a video game sceptic, but now I'm a fan
summary: 'Luke, how do I get this power moon? Luke!” I'm playing Super Mario Odyssey while my partner, Luke, is trying to work. “You'll figure it out,” he says patiently. Luke has been playing video games since he was a child, but this is my first ever game, and he's thrilled that I'm invested in Mario's quest to save Princess Peach. Considering it's a $100bn (£70bn) industry, gaming is a surprisingly “love it, or just don't get it” kind of activity. I've tried video games a few times over the years, as people seemed to be having so much fun with them. But I never got into it. I kept dying, so I gave up. Last year, though, my curiosity was piqued again as I watched Luke play the newest Mario game with

author: DeltaBravo
title: 'Rime' leads the charge for February's PlayStation Plus offerings
summary: Sony revealed February's PlayStation Plus freebies and we think this might just be one of the best slates of offerings in quite some time, especially for PS4 owners with an interest in adventure. PlayStation 4 users can snag Rime, the 2017 puzzle-adventure game that we called gorgeous and moving in our review. In Rime, you play as an unnamed boy who has washed up on a strange island. Rendered in eye-catching cartoonish visuals, you explore the wondrous island, solving puzzles and completing platforming sequences throughout the game's five sections. Rime tells an emotional story that remains a clever mystery until the very end. It's rare that a game as new as Rime finds itself on a PS Plus list,

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: The creator of 'Diablo' is developing an indie dungeon crawler by himself
summary: David Brevik, a veteran game developer who designed and programmed the original Diablo, has a new project in the works. It Lurks Below, a sidescrolling dungeon crawler created solely by Brevik, will launch later this year on Steam, Polygon reports. In some ways, It Lurks Below calls back to Brevik's action RPG roots. It features a class system in which characters level up and scour for loot that gradually makes your character stronger as you progress. In other ways, his new project takes cues from the indie zeitgeist, namely rogue-like mechanics and sandbox creation tools seen in games like Terraria and Minecraft. The game's pixelated visuals give it a retro vibe that many indie developers seem

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: The Business Of Video Games: Surprising Software Sales In 2017 [Infographic]
summary: I have been reading a lot about the performance of the US gaming industry in 2017 so I thought I would throw in my own two cents. It would seem that the overalls sales of video games and video game products are up. In December spending across hardware, accessories, and software grew by 10% when compared to 2016 . Out of these categories, software had a modest increase of 4% overall and 1% during the month of December. That's still an increase of over 300 million US dollars. Software is probably the category that most of us gamers care about the most because it includes the games themselves. Call of Duty: WW2 lead the sales for the year as well as the month December. Call of Duty games have done

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Monopoly releases special edition of board game for cheaters
summary: If you always have to fight the urge to cheat during a game of Monopoly, we have some good news. Realising that players of the beloved board game are prone to breaking the rules to get ahead, Hasbro has created a special edition of the game - where players are actually encouraged to cheat. “Monopoly: Cheater's Edition,” is the version for players who slip a couple hundreds from the bank when the other players aren’t looking.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Could This Video Game Be The 'Call Of Duty' Killer We've Been Waiting For?
summary: Insurgency: Sandstorm is one of my most highly-anticipated first-person shooters of 2018. Recently stripped of its single-player campaign, the game is now 100% multiplayer focused. That was probably the right decision for New World Entertainment to make—doubling down on what's made their previous games so top-notch rather than squandering resources on an expensive campaign. (Note: I'd still love to play a solo campaign made by this team, but I absolutely understand why this has been cut.) In any case, check out this new trailer for the game and tell me it doesn't look absolutely fantastic. One reason it looks so much better than Insurgency or Day of Infamy is the switch from Valve's Source Engine

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Brands and blockchain: How Walmart, Burger King and De Beers are snuggling up to decentralization
summary: Is Bitcoin the future of money? Has the cryptocurrency bubble already popped? It depends who you ask. The topic of Bitcoin is just as polarizing as it is hot. But no matter how volatile Bitcoin stocks may be, its underlying technology, blockchain, has huge potential to transform our industry. Blockchain can clean up the rampant ad fraud and rebuild trust, and more and more companies are popping up to help guide that along. However, it's not just technology companies that are embracing blockchain in its early stages. According to Juniper Research's Blockchain Enterprise Survey, two-thirds of large corporations (defined as having at least 20,000 employees) expect to integrate blockchain by the

author: DeltaBravo
title: Man has his 35 year video game record thrown out, cheated
summary: A gamer lost his Guinness World Record accolade for a video game set in 1982 after a group discovered that he cheated to secure the feat.  Todd Rogers recorded a time of 5.51 seconds for Dragster that was verified by Twin Galaxies, a group specializing in game records, and officially recognized by game designer Activision back on September 1, 1982.  Dragster is a simple timed racing game for the Atari 2600 which first hit shelves in 1977.  Guinness recognized the Rogers' accomplishment in 2001 for being the longest-standing video game record in the world - 35 years.  But a probe from Twin Galaxies would soon find that Rogers was nothing more than a fraud.  'We have notified Guinness World Records

author: captainunderoos
title: Topple giant ogres to save humanity in 'Extinction,' launching April 10
summary: Extinction, a fantasy action game about toppling giant ogres, launches April 10 on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and PC. Iron Galaxy and Modus Games announced the collaborative project at E3 2017 last summer with an impressive reveal trailer, shown above. The game stars Avil, the last of a legendary group of warriors called the Sentinels, in his homeland of Dolorum. Humanity has been overrun by the Ravenii, ogres that tower over buildings and impose their will on a human civilization. As the game's title suggests, the Ravenii must be defeated or else the human race will cease to exist. Combat, designed by Iron Galaxy (Killer Instinct), features a mix of fast-paced acrobatics and hack-and-slash action.

title: Here’s every Xbox One X Enhanced game that supports 4K resolution
summary: Microsoft boasts that its Xbox One X will be the most powerful console ever released, with increased framerates, quicker load times, and 4K resolution. These are the games that can take advantage.

author: DeltaBravo
title: 'PixArk' embraces 'Minecraft' aesthetic
summary: One of the bigger beasts in a packed survival game genre, "Ark: Survival Evolved" has its own very "Minecraft"-esque spin-off coming to Nintendo, Xbox and PC in short order. Snail Games' "PixArk" is "Ark: Survival Evolved" with a recognizably blocky look. The spin-off is being made with the blessing of original "Ark" developer Studio Wildcard but is embracing cuboid crafting, exploration and construction instead of the photorealism of its parent.

author: third_watch
title: I Want To See What Happens When 'Destiny 2' Is Done With Its Apology Tour
summary: The developer of Destiny 2 has been on an apology tour ever since the fan base turned against the game, an experience that felt strong at the beginning but was gradually revealed to be much hollower than its predecessor due to balance changes, uninteresting activity rewards and, most of all, a loot system that feels much more centered around microtransactions than it should be for a paid game. Bungie is doing its best to make good, however, and its been upping both its promises for transparency and, in some instances, its actual transparency. Today we get Masterwork Armor and Raid armor with specific Raid perks, both of which hope to add back in some of the variety that made armor interesting in the original Destiny and was entirely absent from Destiny 2 at launch. Throughout all of this, Bungie has attempted to let players know as much as possible that it's working on it, that it understands their frustrations, and so on.

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: The next Gran Turismo game is already off to the races, producer says
summary: Gran Turismo Sport has only been out for a few months, but work has already begun on its successor, according to the game's producer. It isn't clear if the game will be Gran Turismo 7 or another spinoff.

author: third_watch
title: Fortnite: Battle Royale's Special 'Sniper Shootout' Mode Available, But Not For Long
summary: Fortnite: Battle Royale had some struggles last week as scheduled downtime for maintenance turned into an unexpected, extended downtime followed by a set of bugs that both affected social features and gameplay, but the popular battle royale game has stabilized again by this point. Not only that, but buried inside one of those patches seems to be a brand-new game mode for anyone looking to shake up the standard 100-person deathmatch gameplay: Sniper Shootout, available now until February 2. Sniper Shootout is what it sounds like: Fortnite: Battle Royale but with a whole ton of sniper rifles. All weapon drops have been replaced with snipers save a few revolvers sprinkled in to keep close-quarters

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Microsoft acquires gaming startup PlayFab
summary: SAN FRANCISCO: Microsoft has acquired gaming start-up PlayFab for an undisclosed sum and will integrate its services into Azure platform to help developers build better games. PlayFab powers more than 1,200 live games and has served over 700 million players. "Together, Azure and PlayFab will further unlock the power of the intelligent cloud for the gaming industry, enabling game developers and delighting gamers around the world," Kareem Choudhry, Corporate Vice President of gaming at Microsoft, said in a blog post. PlayFab technology is being used by entertainment companies like Disney, NBC Universal, Wizards of the Coast, Nickelodeon, Bandai Namco, Rovio and Capcom. "Our platform of scalable
